Q10 - Success Metrics: Survey completion rate,Speed of insights,Data accuracy

Q31 - Open Items: Excited about data-driven approach to governance decisions. Let's keep scope tight for MVP.

Q30 - Cultural Considerations: Will this fragment our employee engagement data across too many platforms? We already have Glint running.

Q10 - Success Metrics: Survey completion rate,Action closure rate,Stakeholder engagement
Q18 - Field Worker Distribution: 2200 field workers across Florida Gulf Coast in substations and distribution centers. About 60% without corporate email access.
Q21 - Existing Feedback Tools: Using Glint for culture surveys and pulse checks. Annual engagement survey in October.
Q30 - Cultural Considerations: Glint blackout alignment needed — Dec 15 through Jan 15 all surveys frozen. Also need clarity on who manages the Spanish translation process.
Q31 - Open Items: Ensuring field workers can respond via SMS or QR codes rather than just web links. Email-only approach will miss 60% of our workforce.
Q32 - Biggest Concern: FPL is the largest region with 2200 field workers. Need Spanish version urgently. Happy to pilot.

Q18 - Field Worker Distribution: Distributed across all 14 regions with 70% salaried workforce having email access and 30% hourly or field workers.
Q21 - Existing Feedback Tools: Internal feedback system that is email-based. Will retire after CMX launch.
Q30 - Cultural Considerations: Contact frequency rules: max 1 survey per quarter per employee. Need this codified in governance charter.
Q31 - Open Items: Change fatigue — three major transformation initiatives running simultaneously. People are exhausted by surveys.
Q32 - Biggest Concern: Important to keep intake simple to maximize field worker participation. Less is more.

Q18 - Field Worker Distribution: Field workers concentrated: Florida 35% Carolinas 25% Illinois 20% other regions 20%.
Q21 - Existing Feedback Tools: Stand-alone survey sent via email to managers for cascade to their teams.
Q30 - Cultural Considerations: Need manager escalation workflow for open themes that surface in surveys.
Q31 - Open Items: Regions have different maturity and readiness levels. One-size-fits-all approach won't work. Must allow regional timing flexibility.
Q32 - Biggest Concern: Regional leads need autonomy in timing and communication approach. Central mandates create resistance.

Q18 - Field Worker Distribution: Mix of corporate office and service centers plus distributed field operations. Approximately 4000 field workers without reliable email.
Q21 - Existing Feedback Tools: Qualtrics XM community feedback tool with limited structure.
Q30 - Cultural Considerations: Division Admin access rights definition pending. Need clear RACI for platform governance.
Q31 - Open Items: Getting field workers to respond reliably is the single biggest blocker. Without SMS and QR code approach this program fails for 36% of our workforce.
Q32 - Biggest Concern: SMS and QR approach is absolutely critical. Email-only will not reach our people in the field.

Q25 - API Constraints: 24-month data retention policy. Data purged via automated script quarterly. Legal hold exceptions apply.
Q26 - Metadata Quality: SAP S/4HANA backend. Qualtrics API supported but rate-limited to 1000 calls per day. Workday integration pending API access approval from Legal.
Q32 - Biggest Concern: Workday API access approval requires Legal team sign-off. Currently in queue — estimated 4-6 weeks.
Q33 - Additional Comments: Data governance and compliance. NERC CIP requirements mean survey data might be classified as operational data requiring additional security controls.
column42: Contact Directory quality is the key blocker. Need master data cleanup before any survey launch. Garbage in garbage out.

Q25 - API Constraints: Compliance holds everything for 12 months. Historical data archived to cold storage after that.
Q26 - Metadata Quality: API constraints: webhook latency up to 5 minutes. Batch exports only — no real-time streaming to BI tools.

Q33 - Additional Comments: Duplicate respondent IDs across regions. Need deduplication logic before directory population.

Q32 - Biggest Concern: Real-time dashboard integration not planned for MVP. Manual Tableau refresh acceptable initially.

Q27 - Regional Maturity: FPL is mature and stable. Field workers are organized. Just need good communication cadence and clear role definitions.
Q29 - Regional Lead Availability: Spanish-speaking communities dominant in our region. Union workforce — need careful change messaging. Established employee networks we can leverage.
Q30 - Cultural Considerations: None that I see — FPL is ready to go. We have capacity and willingness.
Q31 - Open Items: Making sure union leadership is involved early. If union reps feel blindsided this will create resistance.
Q32 - Biggest Concern: FPL can be the pilot region if needed. We have capacity and established networks.

Q27 - Regional Maturity: NEER is younger and more distributed across wind farms and solar sites. Different maturity levels across sub-regions. Cannot apply same approach as FPL.
Q29 - Regional Lead Availability: Fast-growing workforce. High turnover in some sub-regions. Remote and transient workers who move between sites.
Q30 - Cultural Considerations: Need flexible launch timeline for different NEER sub-regions. Some are ready now and others need 6 more months.
Q31 - Open Items: Talent retention is unstable — survey fatigue could drive more departures if people feel nothing changes from feedback.
Q32 - Biggest Concern: Consider phased rollout: NEER corporate first then field operations in wave 2.
